Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether 'Tous les juke-box' infringes the copyright of 'Chanson numéro 7'
Procedural_Stage: Trial phase, with remedies (injunction and damages) deferred
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies comparing musical elements; evidence of access to the original work
Decision_Outcome: In favor of the plaintiff, René Grignon
Burden_of_Proof: On the claimant (Grignon) to prove originality, similarity, and access
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony deemed credible in establishing musical resemblance
Legal_Rule: A work is protected under copyright if it is original and in material form; infringement requires substantial similarity and access
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged copying of a protected musical composition
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Proceedings were fair; both parties presented evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Musical analysis by experts, proof of distribution and access to 'Chanson numéro 7'
Legal_Framework: Statutory framework of the Canadian Copyright Act
Applicant_Challenge: Grignon challenged the legality of Roussel's use of his composition
Court_Result: Ruling for the plaintiff on the issue of infringement
Standard_of_Proof: Preponderance of evidence / balance of probabilities
Defendant_Response: Implied denial of copying; no direct statement provided
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert testimony, audio recordings
Outcome: Liability for infringement established; remedies pending
Remedy_Sought: Recognition of infringement, injunctive relief, monetary compensation
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Copyright infringement based on similarity and access
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Permanent injunction and assessment of damages
Governing_Rule: Originality and protection under copyright law; requirement of access and similarity for infringement
